[[Musician]], [[Songwriter]] | years_active = 1940s | label = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]] | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Jack Guthrie''' (13 November 1915 â€“ 15 January 1948) was a songwriter and performer whose rewritten version of the [[Woody Guthrie]] song "[[Oklahoma Hills]]" was a hit in 1945.<ref name="Whitburn, p 40">Whitburn, ''The Billboard Book of Top 40 Country Hits'', p. 146.</ref> The two musicians were cousins.<ref name="guth">Logsdon, Guy, "[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/G/GU005.html Guthrie, Leon Jerry "Jack" (1915-1948)]," ''[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/ Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture]'' (accessed May 26, 2010).</ref> ==Early life== Born '''Leon Jerry Guthrie''' in [[Olive, Oklahoma]], he was the son of the younger brother of Woody Guthrie's father.<ref name="guth"/> He grew up around horses and musical instruments before the family moved to [[California]] in the mid-1930s, where he took on the nicknames "Jack", "Oklahoma", and "Oke".<ref name="guth"/> He competed in rodeo as a bucking-horse rider and in 1937 traveled with Woody to Los Angeles where they landed on the Oke & Woody Show on KFVD radio in Hollywood.<ref name="guth"/> ==Career in music== Guthrie's rewritten version of a Woody Guthrie song "[[Oklahoma Hills]]" (Capitol 201) reached No. 1 in 1945, staying on the charts for 19 weeks.<ref name="Whitburn, p 40"/> The b side, "I'm A Brandin' My Darlin' With My Heart", reached No. 5 later that year. At the time the record became a hit Jack Guthrie was in the [[U.S. Army]] and stationed in the [[Pacific Ocean theater of World War II|Pacific Theater]]. As soon as he got out of the service he wrote and recorded more songs, played live [[Gig (musical performance)|gig]]s up and down the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]]. His version of "[[Oakie Boogie]]" (Capitol 341), a hit at No. 3 in 1947, is considered a candidate for the [[first rock and roll record]]. In July 1947 he was admitted to a hospital with [[tuberculosis]]. He died in 1948 in [[Livermore, California|Livermore]], [[California]]. Guthrie's style was influenced by [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] and adapted to fit his cowboy image.<ref name="guth"/> Although the labels listed ''Jack Guthrie and His Oklahomans'' as the artist, in reality Guthrie had no band. The studio brought in some of its better musicians to back Guthrie. Many of them, [[Porky Freeman]], [[Red Murrell]], [[Cliffie Stone]], and [[Billy Hughes (musician)|Billy Hughes]] among them, were stars in their own right. ==See also== *[[Oklahoma Hills (album)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *Whitburn, Joel.
